header.title: orddict

description.p: Orddict implements a Key - Value dictionary. An orddict is a representation of a dictionary, where a list of pairs is used to store the keys and values. The list is ordered after the keys.

This module provides exactly the same interface as the module dict but with a defined representation. One difference is that while dict considers two keys as different if they do not match (=:=), this module considers two keys as different if and only if they do not compare equal (==).

func.name: append(Key, Value, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Append a value to keys in a dictionary

desc.p: This function appends a new Value to the current list of values associated with Key. An exception is generated if the initial value associated with Key is not a list of values.

func.name: append_list(Key, ValList, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Append new values to keys in a dictionary

desc.p: This function appends a list of values ValList to the current list of values associated with Key. An exception is generated if the initial value associated with Key is not a list of values.

func.name: erase(Key, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Erase a key from a dictionary

desc.p: This function erases all items with a given key from a dictionary.
This function returns the value associated with Key in the dictionary Orddict. fetch assumes that the Key is present in the dictionary and an exception is generated if Key is not in the dictionary.

func.name: fetch_keys(Orddict) -> Keys
func.fsummary: Return all keys in a dictionary

desc.p: This function returns a list of all keys in the dictionary.

func.name: filter(Pred, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Choose elements which satisfy a predicate

desc.p: Orddict2 is a dictionary of all keys and values in Orddict1 for which Pred(Key, Value) is true.

func.name: find(Key, Orddict) -> {ok, Value} | error
func.fsummary: Search for a key in a dictionary

desc.p: This function searches for a key in a dictionary. Returns {ok, Value} where Value is the value associated with Key, or error if the key is not present in the dictionary.

func.name: fold(Fun, Acc0, Orddict) -> Acc1
func.fsummary: Fold a function over a dictionary

desc.p: Calls Fun on successive keys and values of Orddict together with an extra argument Acc (short for accumulator). Fun must return a new accumulator which is passed to the next call. Acc0 is returned if the list is empty. The evaluation order is undefined.

func.name: from_list(List) -> Orddict
func.fsummary: Convert a list of pairs to a dictionary

desc.p: This function converts the Key - Value list List to a dictionary.

func.name: is_key(Key, Orddict) -> bool()
func.fsummary: Test if a key is in a dictionary

desc.p: This function tests if Key is contained in the dictionary Orddict.

func.name: map(Fun, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Map a function over a dictionary

desc.p: map calls Func on successive keys and values of Orddict to return a new value for each key. The evaluation order is undefined.

merge merges two dictionaries, Orddict1 and Orddict2, to create a new dictionary. All the Key - Value pairs from both dictionaries are included in the new dictionary. If a key occurs in both dictionaries then Fun is called with the key and both values to return a new value. merge could be defined as:
desc.code: merge(Fun, D1, D2) -> fold(fun (K, V1, D) -> update(K, fun (V2) -> Fun(K, V1, V2) end, V1, D) end, D2, D1).
desc.p: but is faster.
This function creates a new dictionary.

func.name: size(Orddict) -> int()
func.fsummary: Return the number of elements in an ordered dictionary

desc.p: Returns the number of elements in an Orddict.

func.name: store(Key, Value, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Store a value in a dictionary

desc.p: This function stores a Key - Value pair in a dictionary. If the Key already exists in Orddict1, the associated value is replaced by Value.

func.name: to_list(Orddict) -> List
func.fsummary: Convert a dictionary to a list of pairs

desc.p: This function converts the dictionary to a list representation.

func.name: update(Key, Fun, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Update a value in a dictionary

desc.p: Update a value in a dictionary by calling Fun on the value to get a new value. An exception is generated if Key is not present in the dictionary.

func.name: update(Key, Fun, Initial, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Update a value in a dictionary

desc.p: Update a value in a dictionary by calling Fun on the value to get a new value. If Key is not present in the dictionary then Initial will be stored as the first value. For example append/3 could be defined as:
desc.code: append(Key, Val, D) -> update(Key, fun (Old) -> Old ++ [Val] end, [Val], D).

func.name: update_counter(Key, Increment, Orddict1) -> Orddict2
func.fsummary: Increment a value in a dictionary

desc.p: Add Increment to the value associated with Key and store this value. If Key is not present in the dictionary then Increment will be stored as the first value.
This could be defined as:
desc.code: update_counter(Key, Incr, D) -> update(Key, fun (Old) -> Old + Incr end, Incr, D).
desc.p: but is faster.

section.title: Notes
section.p: The functions append and append_list are included so we can store keyed values in a list accumulator. For example:
section.pre: > D0 = orddict:new(), D1 = orddict:store(files, [], D0), D2 = orddict:append(files, f1, D1), D3 = orddict:append(files, f2, D2), D4 = orddict:append(files, f3, D3), orddict:fetch(files, D4). [f1,f2,f3]
section.p: This saves the trouble of first fetching a keyed value, appending a new value to the list of stored values, and storing the result.
The function fetch should be used if the key is known to be in the dictionary, otherwise find.
